    The First Level of Super Mario Bros. is Easy with Lexicographic Orderings and Time Travel... after that it gets a little tricky

    Sep 23, 2015

    The title of this post is actually the title of a research paper (pdf) written by Tom Murphy (@tom7). The paper, which describes how computers might learn to play Super Mario Bros., was submitted to SIGBOVIK ‘13 (“[..] a yearly conference celebrating the inestimable research work of Harry Quasi-bovik Bovik”). A conference described by Tom as “an April 1 conference that usually publishes fake research”.

     

    On the conference’s website we can read that SIGBOVIK is “traditionally a forum for discussion on many subjects”. What follows is a list of inexplicable subjects including “Rasterized Love Triangles”, “Regret-Minimizing Algorithms” and “Science”. Tom’s research led him to develop two programs (playfun & learnfun) that allow Tom to sit back and watch his computer mostly fail, but also succeed (sometimes in spectacularly glitching fashion) at NES games.

     

    Unlike most papers (I’ve read), Tom’s is thorougly lucid, irreversibly deepened my understanding of programming and machine learning, contained colourful screenshots of NES games and was a blast to read (“Caching of emulation” is one subchapter, “Color a dinosaur” another).

     

     

    Alongside the paper Tom took the time to record three videos</b> that serve as a showcase of his work. If you have an hour to spare and are interested in watching a computer program play Bubble Bobble, Tetris and figure out glitches in Super Mario Bros., be sure to check out these videos.
